Hi, all. I am not sure where to post this. I am going to start a class next week. In the past, I’ve used Python, but now it is Julia time! :juliaspinner:

I set up a Jupyter Hub in AWS EC2 and install conda+python in `/opt/conda` , with a specified user group. Then all students are added to the group and everything works fine, at least with python. Now, I want to set up a common Julia environment, already installed with every package they need for the course, and without having the students struggle with installation issues.

So the question is whether I can simply install julia into something like `/opt/julia`, with the same user group, add the jupyter kernel associate with it, and that is it? Nothing weird to expect?

text:
Great question that I am stumbling across for different reasons today. I think you would want to
1. install Julia
2. install Conda.jl
    a. `]`
    b. `add Conda`
3. `import Conda`
4. create a new conda environment
    c. easiest way I found was to enter shell mode with  (`;`) and run `conda create -n <envname>`
    d. the alternative (which wasn't as easy in my case) is to use <https://github.com/JuliaPy/Conda.jl/blob/master/src/Conda.jl#L126|Conda.runconda>
5. Then you can add packages by running `Conda.add(<packagename>, <path/to/env")`
This is how I would go about it.  Would like to know if there is something I am missing or an easier way.
